content: I have recently been congratulating a new user on the italian board for his astonishing Merit/Post ratio. This particular user is a well known expert user in the italian community, and already provided good content here on the forum, where he’s new. So this ratio is quite expected. As he’s pretty new to the forum, he asked me “what is a great merit/post ratio?. comments.body: Interesting post.  Statistics can be skewered in any direction.  You might want to go back and filter out the shower of merits to and from merit sources who have their favourites they snow ball merits in closed circles.  Plus, you might want to remove some of the super threads where the users just endlessly merit each-others posts even though they have no substance.

comments.author: DdmrDdmr
comments.body: When I used to do analysis rather frequently back in the day, I looked at the Merit per post ratio, and one of the difficulties in compiling or interpreting the data is the fact that quite a few accounts had many posts created before the introduction of the Merit System, which normally would drag down their result (except for the likes of  Hal, Satoshi, Laszlo and so forth). Other less prominent long-standing accounts will have a lower ratio due to their pre-Merit System posting backlog, when comparted to accounts born into the Merit System.To a certain degree, an ideal criteria would more or less play around with the post count at the time the Merit System kicked-off, and device how to use that in the calculus (i.e. if an account is pre-Merit System, but posted mostly/largely after it kicked-off, consider the post count at the time the Merit System kicked-off, and not the total number of posts). Another interesting variation, subject to the same problematic as the one said above, is to calculate the percentage of merited posts, which gives a sense of broadness to the merit/post ratio. comments.author: joker_josue
comments.body: Quote from: fillippone on January 11, 2023, 04:02:23 PMI have recently been congratulating a new user on the italian board for his astonishing Merit/Post ratio. This particular user is a well known expert user in the italian community, and already provided good content here on the forum, where he’s new. So this ratio is quite expected. As he’s pretty new to the forum, he asked me “what is a great merit/post ratio?. First of all, congratulations for another analysis. It's always good to be able to see things from different perspectives, to have an idea of how things are evolving.Now, I think this type of relationship is very subjective and doesn't exactly mean that a user with little posts and many merits is better than others. Because a user who makes few quality posts and is not very active, who receives many deserved merits, will always have a better ratio than a user who makes quality topics and is very active (where logically not all participations deserve merit) will have a ratio lower.
